p: It is known that occluding the external auditory meatus lowers the hearing threshold for bone-conducted sound. This is known as the occlusion effect ( 7, 8). The occlusion of the external auditory meatus improves hearing thresholds by 10â€“20 dB at frequencies of 250 and 500 Hz ( 7, 9). Therefore, occluding the external auditory meatus might improve VEMP responses. Handzel and Himmelfarb ( 10) reported that cVEMP responses could be augmented by occlusion. We applied this method to oVEMP recording in order to obtain stable oVEMP responses using the B81.
